awd_titl_txt: SaTC: CORE: Small: Collaborative: An Integrated Approach for Enterprise Intrusion-Resilience
awd_abstract_narration:
The recent prevalence of advanced cyber attacks has caused enterprise breaches with severe consequences in critical sectors, such as national defense, manufacturing and the financial industry. Current defense practices rely on attack prevention and detection technologies, but our understanding of the capabilities of these security tools against truly advanced threats, which rapidly grow in sophistication, is severely lacking. This project seeks to harden enterprise security against advanced threats by systematically designing a new multi-layer intrusion-resilient framework that addresses individual enterprise defenses, as well as global, community-based protections. Overall, with a focus on educational activities, outreach to under-represented minority groups and technology transfer to industry, this project aims at contributing a new holistic defense approach to the security community that increases the security stance of our national infrastructures. 
  
This project develops a new framework for enterprise intrusion resilience that: (1) protects both individual assets and enterprises as a whole; (2) adapts to attacker's strategies by devising security tools that are themselves resilient to breaches; and (3) promotes new coordinated protections across enterprises and industry sectors while protecting the privacy of shared data. These solutions leverage cryptography, game-theoretical modeling, and community-based defenses to provide strong intrusion resilience against advanced threats. The investigators plan to engage actively with the security industry to evaluate their techniques in practical settings and provide concrete recommendations on local and coordinated defensive strategies for protecting our national infrastructures. By educating students and cyber professionals, as well as conducting a range of outreach activities to the community, this project seeks to increase awareness of emerging attack techniques and best proactive defenses for successfully mitigating the cyber attacks of the future.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
With the increased sophistication of cyber adversaries, protecting national infrastructures against a range of cyber attacks is a challenge that needs to be addressed. Modern cyber attacks can propagate independently on the Internet, reaching hundreds of thousands of vulnerable users, as evidenced by the Mirai IoT campaign and the WannaCry ransomware attack. Some sophisticated attacks can remain stealthy in compromised systems for months and even years. An example of this behavior is the recent SolarWinds attack, which introduced a vulnerability in a network monitoring software installed in many corporate and government networks, and used it to extract sensitive information from the compromised networks. Existing cyber defense techniques are oftentimes not sufficient for detecting these sophisticated attacks, as attackers develop methods to exploit common services and protocols, and hide in the large volumes of normal activities. 

The intellectual merit of this project is the development of a framework that enables a holistic view on cyber security defenses, by using techniques from game theory, artificial intelligence (AI), and formal methods. We model various cyber defense strategies using a game theoretical model in which we can reason about the cost to defend a single organization against attacks, and compute optimal defensive strategies. In this framework, we showed the benefit of deploying adaptive defensive strategies, in which a defender actively learns from the attacker's behavior and optimizes its defensive strategy, using reinforcement learning techniques. Additionally, we designed several AI-based defense systems for specific attack vectors. PORTFILER is an AI-based system that learns the normal activity in a network and detects ?self-propagating? cyber attacks such as WannaCry and Mirai. LOLAL is an active learning system for detecting ?living-off-the-land malware?, an attack that leverages existing legitimate tools in the target system, making it very difficult to detect with regular anti-virus and endpoint tools. Lastly, we have designed global, community-based protections that involve coordination among multiple organizations to protect against cyber attacks, while preserving the privacy of the data collected at each organization. 

Our research under this grant has resulted in a range of broader impacts, including publications in cybersecurity conferences and recognition with an Outstanding Student Award at the 2019 Conference on Decision and Game Theory for Security (GameSec) for the work on game theoretical models of cybersecurity. Our PORTFILER system was deployed on two university networks for several months and detected various malicious activities, which were not identified by existing security tools. We have educated students, practitioners, and the public on various issues related to modern cyber attacks and how to think about deploying multi-layer comprehensive defenses.  The project has created many opportunities for undergraduate and graduate students to perform research in cybersecurity, AI, and formal methods, and solve some of the challenges of securing our national infrastructures. Through our interaction with  industry collaborators and the deployment of open-source tools, this work has influenced the design of next-generation AI-based defense systems. 

 

 

 


Last Modified: 11/04/2021
Modified by: Alina M Oprea
